It comes with chopped chicken with the bone, a by product of making the stock with only whole stewing hens. The chicken meat robust and slightly chewy. If your Pho shop doesn't meet the required needs above for Pho gà, what other items might not be authentic?

The guy at the front desk was horrible and not friendly whatsoever, extremely rude. The asian guy (I think his name is Daniel) who was actually with us during axe throwing was awesome and the 4 stars are for him and his service. This place needs more employees like him that actually make the experience a good time rather than having the monotone, rude, probably high dude in the front. Will probably be back once restrictions aren't as limited, it was hot in there and the bar was closed.

Pigeons won't starve for food, but patrons will starve for attention and hospitality at this establishment. What a shame too. The food was good. I had the warm lentils over greens with a think slice of rye bread and poached eggs done to perfection. The pastries looked delicious. The setting that included tables as well as countertop dining was right up my alley. And the one, drip coffee option was a smooth medium roast that did not disappoint. But the staff left me and my guest feeling less them welcomed and no desire to return.

Noodle, they are industrialized Noodle and not a daily made product. Egg, it's like the best soft boiled since yolk is half harden. Broth, not flavorful for ramen Broth and no mixing whatsoever. Can't believe this is second chain already in Philly. Don't recommend foodie to go. Time to level up ramen choice if you want something better.

I came down specially to eat here from Bucks County. I've eaten there before love it ..order drinks at the bar. My craft beer came out perfect The margaritas were 5% tequila and 95% lime juice . The cocktail was Undrinkable... left and went somewhere else, had a great time!
This Applebee's is so convenient right at Henry and ridge ave. All Applebee's taste the same, but this one has a very friendly staff and the restaurant is generally clean

I ordered GrubHub at approximately 11:30 pm and received my food at 12:30 am. I ordered Crab Rangoon (delicious), KimChi (could have been bigger for the price-was served in a half-pint container for $4), Vegetable and Bean curd soup-pint (delicious), and Ma Po Tofu, also delicious. I read previous reviews before ordering this food, and am a regular when it comes to eating Asian food throughout the city... and I check Yelp a lot before I go somewhere. Just like Henry P. said.. I'm glad I didn't listen to the Yelp users that only use Yelp to review businesses on a negative level-you know, the ones who expect to be treated like they're eating at a five star restaurant and expect to get that tier of food delivered and pay $12 to do so. Wake up. Delivery came on time, and the price was right. I'll order again.

HUGE slices of pizza and it doesn't taste like a rubber. If you haven't had a slice of pizza that takes up the entire pizza box, then you have to stop by here. Definitely a good way to soak up all that alcohol after a night out on South Street or wherever you have gotten your fix!
If you're looking for a good quality cheese steak it's at Sonny's! Good service and not expensive at all!

I can remember when Joey experimented with the cheap cheese cr*ps uses across the street. I said to Joey I'd gladly pay more for kraft cheese. The comment was dismissed so I decided no more Wizz and after 1 year of no Wizz fries kraft was back. Now Geno I beg you please stop serving that meat. Go over to Joe's aka (chinks) and taste the product. It is by far the best cheesesteak I've had to date. Make geno's what it once was the best cheesesteak in Philly

This is a pizza landmark on Frankford Ave for many many years.....nothing has changed.......they are probably the oldest business on that part of the ave.......same owner.....same recipe. ....that tells you something.....

I didn't really know it was a British gastropub. A friend invited me for lunch. I climbed many stairs. I ordered an iced tea with simple syrup. It was so bitter. I sent it back and ordered a watery glass of Rose, there was only one choice. I had the house salad, swimming in a lemony dressing. Had to ask for bread, salt. Service was accommodating, generally. I was happy to see my friend & wI'll not bother to return to Dandelion.

Great spot to people watch and enjoy a bottle of wine and maybe and appetizer but if you are hungry and looking for an authentic French Bistro.... Go somewhere else. I have given this place 4 chances for the kitchen to impress me and it's been a disappointment every time. The food lacks flavor! I have tried, Steak, Sandwiches, Salads, and Fish and everything seemed to be very bland. I will give the escargot a 10 but 9.5 points of that score comes from the massive amount of butter used in the sauce. Anything floating in butter is delicious! I believe this is my least favorite Steven Starr production. The service is always friendly and professional..
Like Wawa, but with much better food and an ATM that costs money. Just had a vegetarian chicken hoagie from Palm Tree Market and it was way good.
this gearo's closed...they only have the one on welsh road. welsh road one isn't doing so well either

this place is oozing history, from the rat pack to joe dimaggio and including but not limited to guests such as, lillian russell, bob hope and richard nixon they have all came and left their mark. It hosted presidents, local politicians, countless international dignitaries and celebrities. In the 1950s and 1960s, devotees of its famous five-pound lobsters included elizabeth taylor and many many others. In later years, bookbinder's continued to attract a celebrated following including david bowie, madonna, and muhammad ali. bookbinders is a philadelphia landmark, that i basically never go to. so uhm yea.
The jerk wings/sauce and chicken foot soup are great when they have it. They never keep it regularly.

I bought a $50 groupon for Kokopelli on a friend's recommendation and was anxious to try it out. My boyfriend and I went there on Saturday night before a concert and ordered 5 plates between the two of us. Honestly, nothing was good. And a few things were really bad. The bison sliders were inedible. The shrimp wasn't far behind...and I LOVE food and usually can find positives at most places. The atmosphere is nice, waitress was very pleasant...but they really need to step up their kitchen or they will be out of business quite soon with all the amazing other options available to us in this amazing food-filled city.

Two things: We love Tim. Tim is the best bartender. We met Tim when he was just a server, then a bar back, and now he's our favorite bartender. Give him a raise. But....the bald guy! He's the worst. He's got a smug attitude and his customer service sucks. One time when serving us, his reply to how he was doing was, "You know, I'm at work." Hmm... get a new job then. Tonight, while sitting at the bar I heard him say "cheap asses" as he looked at the tip that was left him on a tab. It's probably cause you're not a personable guy!

My husband and I were serviced 12-27-15. Our sever (Edward M), appeared to be overwhelmed with his tables he was responsible for. He served the table on my right and left, but didn't acknowledge us right away. Five minutes later, he asked us for a drink order. We ordered. My Husband also mentioned, we didn't have saucers for our loaf of bread. He came back with 2 saucers to accommodate us. Our dinner was very tasty. Although he forgot my vegetable, I waited and caught him at another table to tell him. He served us hastily. ÇF was good, but waiter was so so.

What can I say, Naked Chocolate Cafe is delish! I was in need of cupcakes for a birthday party recently and not sure where to acquire them. I visited Yelp! and found tons of rave reviews of this place. Everyone was right on. A word to the wise: don't show up on a Saturday morning and order a dozen cupcakes unless you're ready for the snarky guy behind the counter to inform you that bulk orders need to be made 24 hours in advance. Would you believe this happened to me? Fortunately he was able to fill the order and my fellow party-goers were quite happy.

Me: "Where's your favorite place to eat here?" Philly Native: "Have you had a cheesesteak yet?" Me: "(Sigh) I had Pat's and Geno's. Wasn't impressed." Philly Native: "Oh, you gotta have Jim's." Me: "Okay." [Cut to me sitting across from my friend at Jim's.] Philly Native: "Isn't this better?" Me: (Lying, so as not to hurt his feelings.) "Oh yeah." Sorry, Philly cheesesteaks. After three strikes, yer out.

Not sure why this place gets such rave reviews or always has such an extensive wait (constantly crowding the sidewalk). Service has always been fine (I've only been at "off-peak" weekday hours with no wait). Food is mediocre - at best. There are plenty of other places in the neighborhood to get a great brunch without the wait.

I sit in my car on a Fairmount side street. I was worried about parking, but found an ok place near 27th st. I hadnt gone bar hopping in decades, frankly, even when I was young and pretty, I didnt really do it all that much. But here i was today. I was to meet a few friends to check out a few of the local bars. I took my cellphone, car keys, and grabbed my Costanza-like wallet. " Do I really need this? " I thought I decided to just take my money and credit card, and that I probably wouldnt need my Acme card for this. I lingered over my license, wondering if I would need it. I chuckled to myself. Ive been going grey since 19. In pictures I often look older than my dad. Even with a little help from JFM (Just for Men) I NEVER get carded. So in the first of what would be a series of bad decisions over the night, I left my ID in the car. North Star wasnt the first bar we hit that night, but we werent drunk when we got there. It looked like a cool place from the outside. A couple of tricked out Harleys stood out front. I wondered what kind of crowd was in there and if they would see my flame colored hawaiian shirt as a cry for help. A large intimidatig black man was leaning on a mailbox, talking animatedly on a Bluetooth. His bass-like voice filled the quiet street. I was not savy enough to realize that this was a bouncer. We dont have bouncers in the Burbs. We went to walk in. " Excuse me Gentlemen! Can I see your ID?" he bellowed He couldnt mean me. My friends showed their IDs and began to walk in. I was realizing that I had made a huge mistake by not bringing ID " Hey guys!" I mumbled, " I dont have my ID" The bouncer still stood there but was back into his phone conversation. one of my friends turned around and told me to come anyway, as he couldnt have meant for my old ass to show ID. I began to walk in until I felt a hand on my shoulder. " Hey!" , he said sharply, " were you just going to go in and ignore me!" My mind raced. Was I going to get my ass kicked? Was I going to run away? Was I going to make a smart-ass comment that would increse my chances of getting my ass kicked? I optioned for being apologetic.I realized that this guy knew i was of age but it was his territory and he ruled over it. I also realized that he wanted to F* with me. He admonished me, told me to bring my ID next time and told me I could go in. Inside, it looked like a really cool dive bar. We stayed in the front bar. Apparently there is a back bar with a stage for live music. There was a concert going on but we werent interested, and to avoid paying a cover, we opted to stay in the front. We got a table with extremely uncomfortable stools. The crowd was diverse, the good , the bad and the tattooed. I guess the band playing dictates the crowd, a lot of black clothing alot of tattoos. My friend bought me a beer to make up for almost getting me killed by the bouncer, so I didnt deal with the bartender. They looked the part, and i noticed there was a computer with Youtube on it behind the bar. I wondered the signifigance of that. I had a Guiness to clear the pallate after the Belgian beers we had earlier. I was hungry, and I heard that the burgers were good here. There was a chalkboard advertizing an Olympic Burger, which was basically a souped up cheeseburger served with onion rings instead of fries. (get it! ? Olympic rings) I wanted it. Plus I heard somewhere to always try the special when you go to a new place and may not go again. We called a waitress over and I adored her from the moment she tripped over my friend's bodybag-like backpack. She was cute and friendly and even though she was really busy, gave us her time and didnt rush away. It was loud in there but not so loud that we couldnt have a conversation. Plus , we could hear the music from the concert without having to pay. Suckers! I didnt get the same vibe as in Bridgids, about interacting with other patrons. Everyone basically stayed in their own group. My burger was fantastic. Ill have to go back sometime when i hadnt had 4 beers so i can really enjoy it. The waitress checked on us often. This is not something im used to in the burb bars that are often less busy.It was time to go. As we walked out I passed my friend, the bouncer. He shouted in my direction, " Whats the score!?" I stopped. He said the same thing 2 more times. It wouldnt be wise to ignore him again , but what score? Phillies? Eagles? Me vs Him ( hes winning 1-0) I turned and said, "which score?" He looked at me like an idiot. Of course. the Bluetooth again, i HATE those things. He wasnt talking to me. Why does every outing end with me looking like an ass. Overall I gave it 4stars. I didnt really take any points off for either Bouncer incident, as it was mostly my fault and he was just doing his job. It was a cool place with good food and good service.

I am a regular. I love this place. I am very close to making another choice. The food has gone way down in the past couple of months. Even the go tos food classic like wings taste off. A lot of food taste frozen. A lot of burgers and fries are inconsistent. It is is breaking my heart. The owner has been observed yelling at this staff one too many times. It is so uncomfortable. The staff is the MAIN reason why we (and many) others come. I am worried...I hope that this gets their attention to bring in quality ingredients and cooks ASAP!

The meat is complete and juicy. You have the options of cheeses and if you want to be disrespectful and go non traditional they got options as well. The parking is a bust but does not deter us from the specialty food!

The food was okay, but the service is terrible. The waiter took 15 minutes till he asked us what we wanted to order even though we were the only customers present, forgot the order after three seconds, and took our plates away before we finished our food.
I invariably get pad thai at every thai place I go. I just love it when it is good. This was one of the more disappointing ones I've had in the city.

2 beers + 1 sardine* order = $7.66 No my math is not wrong and no I am not crazy. You are crazy! Crazy for not going to ASB's happy hour every day (M-F 4-6, Sa & Su 11-1). Half priced cans. Half priced selection of food. Ahhhmazing. *If you are like me, you think sardines are teeny teeny tiny. You are wrong. ASB is the land of huge sardines. No, not like tuna fish huge, but like sardines on steroids huge. Who knew???

After reading some reviews on here about service, I'm wondering how many went through a delivery service site like GrubHub or Seamless. I placed an order tonight through Seamless, and THEY were the ones who messed up. Before I even received a confirmation from Seamless, I received a call from Manny's telling me that they were out a veal parm and asked if chicken would be fine. After that call, I received my confirmation email from Seamless. Seven minutes later, I received another from Seamless telling me that my order was NOT confirmed and that they are refunding my order. I called Manny's back, and, sure enough, my order was about to leave the door. I called Seamless to let them know that everything was fine, and they had to call Manny's AGAIN for a confirmation, which they promptly received. When my order arrived (extremely promptly, by the way), I gave the delivery person an extra tip as an apology for the Seamless confusion. I'm now eating my dinner, and it's wonderful. Great chicken parm grinder and Old Bay fries. Next time I place an order from Manny's, I'm calling them directly!

Still the best place to get a great hoagie for a great price. I live about a 15 min drive from this place an i dont like driving but will take the drive to get their hoagies. The place is often packed if you go between 11-2 an between 5-7. Even on the off hours this place may or may not be packed its the luck of the draw. Today i got lucky no one in front of me however as i ordered my hoagies 5 people came in right behind me. The only caveat is the parking. It is smack in the corner across from a fire station an a few local hotspot bars on a busy street. I went to a deli that i never been to on a trip to shore with a few friends. The hoagie there was bland roll was hard an at $ 6 bucks. The next day i bought Major hoagies an everyone was shocked especially when i said it was only 3.75. What i like about this place if i say Light Mayo its light mayo other places you order your hoagie with light Mayo an still smack a bunch on. . I had about 30 hoagies from this place in the past 4 years an never had a bad one. One word do not attempt to park illegally. The A-Holes parking authority frequently prowl this area like a lion prowls a wounded Antelope.

Two of us wandering Main Street Manayunk thinking about food are greeted effusively by Zesty's hostess. Clearly this was to be the place. We took outdoor seating as it was reasonably cool for a summer's evening. The Hostess explained the menu and took drink orders. I had the house Merlot. Not bad for a bottom of the price range house wine. My wife had Spanikopita and I had the Ravioli Verde. Served promptly and tasted great. The owner or manager came by several times during our meal and the waiter, Shahab, checked the water, wine, etc. frequently but not obtrusively. There are quite a few things on the menu we'd like to check out so we will be back.

Elevated vegetarian food! Complex flavors! Highly recommend! The meatballs had notes of harissa almost, not bland at all! The nachos were light and the vegan cheese was delightful! Really impressed with such a creative and flavorful menu! Not sure why the appetizer prices are the same as the entrees. Our waiter was a white male, forgot his name but he seemed frustrated when we couldn't decide on the menu. The menu on their website does not match the menu they have the QR code which threw us off. He literally rolled his eyes when my friend needed a couple of more minutes. Went on 1/12/22 for dinner.

Super grateful to have a place like this in fairmount! By the vast demand and lines out the door you can tell that it has been ovedue. The coffee that I got had spoiled milk. It is not the first time I have ordered a coffee with spoiled milk and I recognize it can happen but when I sent it back and asked for a new one the barrista told me that the milk was definitley not spoiled. Okay....I guess. He begrudgingly gave me a new coffee and I put the milk in myself from where the help yourself things were and round two (without the spoiled milk) was better. It has a nice serene atmosphere and is a nice addition to the neighborhood.

Lone salesman looking to eat. Sat at the bar was served promptly, beer was cold and fairly priced. Ordered the salmon, which can be risky-usually comes out dry. Bar Amis cooked it perfectly. Well done!

Simple saying here -- the bread of their format tasted real good and won't be spoiled for at least 24 hours in brown bag. Enjoyable edible. Nothing fancier than that and have not tried to eat inside yet. Stay turned!

While the atmosphere was good and the staff accommodating at first for a large party, the manager quickly realized that having an additional 20 people fill his otherwise sparsely filled bar was too much for him to handle at midnight on a Saturday. Once 1am tolled he quickly stood on a stool and shouted "leave!" gesticulating towards the exit. I don't plan on going back.

YES: -Happy hour. They have a killer happy hour. Get the buns, the curds, the cranberry mule. Set. -Cheese curds. They deserve their own bullet. Seriously, I don't know how they managed to pull off such a fantastic menu item. -Dessert. Whiskey bourbon bread pudding is delicious. Need to try that funetti cake. -Cocktails. They seem to have the mixing game down. -Bathrooms. Super cute and private stalls. There's only three unisex stalls, however, so you may need to wait. -Tiki bar. Bring it back! Such a lovely reprieve from the winter. From what the host said prior to its December closing, the owners are considering re-opening it each winter as a seasonal pop-up. I really hope they do! It was adorable and so welcoming. -Bar seats. So cute, retro and comfy! NO: -Beer. Do not bother. My requested $7 brown ale was a grand cru. I pointed it out and the server told me I was wrong. I was actually not wrong. Small pour too. -Fried chicken. I don't understand. The chicken was dry and boring. The bun was dry and boring. How do all the critics love this dry and boring plate? Or did I just get a poor plate courtesy of Restaurant Week? -High tops behind the bar. I made a RW res at the beginning of January, so when we were pointed to the first high top in front of the door, I requested a different table. Hostess replied by staring at me without using words. I then said, "Um, can we have this one then?" (Aka the high-top one back). She hesitantly said okay, but it didn't matter anyway. As a chronically cold person, I froze the whole meal. And the seat was painful. VERDICT: No to Restaurant Week. Yes to Happy Hour. I'd gladly go back and eat/drink their entire HH menu whenever possible. If I did go back for a full meal, I'd request a table in the dining area away from the door. And order a cocktail. Lesson learned.
Service was really nice especially during these hard times and was hard to order and pay.

From the steamy air and mounds of fresh bagels, you would think this place would make the best bagels ever. It doesn't. Too airy, flat, and the texture a little soft and crumbly. I prefer Philadelphia Bagel Factory and New York Bagel Bakery (althoughneither are perfect). Don't get me wrong, this place is still waaay better than the garbage other places call bagels.

It pains me to give only two stars, but the shop has declined over the past year. Last fall, the donuts were absolutely perfect. Slightly crispy, soft on the inside, and filled/covered with amazingness. But recently, the shop has gotten so busy that they cant keep up with demand; in response it appears that they stopped cooking the donuts for as long and consequently, more than 50% of the time, the donuts are undercooked. The flavors are still there, but they are almost too doughy to enjoy most days. I cant possibly express my disappointment here as beiler's used to be one of my "must go"s for people visiting and living in Philly... PLEASE, PLEASE work on it!
I went to this restaurant many times last year; loved the BYOB, and the food. It appears to have been closed for months. . . Will they re-open? Any update on this from anyone?

My mouth and eyes really liked this pizza; they were all like "we're ready to eat some pizza - we got this" and it was delicious. My stomach and the rest of gi track really hated this pizza, like a lot....A LOT It's really up to you and which body parts you want to make happy. As for me, I will not be putting myself through that again.

Great food - Christmas Day evening menu fixed with 3 of 5 appetizers available. All entrees available. Food was 5 stars!! Prime Rib and Seven Fish Entrees - salads wonderful - dessert perfect! Will go back for the food. View - eh!!!!! Service very poor! We went for good food and got it and hope Christmas evening staff and service was just due to the fact it is a holiday - but I doubt it. Way understaffed ! Staff were actually running to keep up! I feel sorry for the staff. They say restaurants with a great city view are all show - and this was true today EXCEPT food was damn good!!

I love coming to this place for pizza. I asked for the slice with sausage and pepperoni but was told they didn't have any. Julio saved the day and told me he would put the pepperoni on my slice, no extra charge!! What a great team they have down there. See you guys real soon!!!

We have been eating at the Conshy location - which is a full restaurant- for many years. The restaurants have great breakfast, salads, etc. This location is for pizza products and garlic bread only IMHO. It's true - you will like or hate this pizza. That's the whole point of it! This location is smaller so it's a different experience but pizza is the same. The pizza is exactly like each review says - whether it's a positive or negative one. Sounds crazy but my son and I love it and my other 2 kids think it's horrible. So even in our family we are split. It doesn't make sense to me for people to say pizza should be a certain way. Each place makes pizza differently. If you have a sweet tooth and like a lot of sauce and thin/breads crust (not crispy) - you will like this. Otherwise you will not. So try it - and if it's not for you then move on. I do think the delivery issues are important and although they warn you - delivery times are at least an hour. They deliver to us even though we are technically outside the area that the website says they deliver to you. And if you call from your landline you don't have to give them your address - makes me nuts that every week I have to tell our fav Chinese take out place our address and phone number. So - the reason that the reviews are so split is because it's a very unique pizza. You will always know if your eating a Franzones pizza. My son and I say pour in the sugar and slather with sauce - we even order it w extra sauce. We need forks to eat it because it's soft. My other kids would rather starve then eat this pizza. So to each their own with Franzones.

Foodery, You bedazzle me with your diverse beer collection You bewilder me with your steep prices You befuddle me with your name I know I shalt use the Mix a 6 pack to receive the customary 10% dicount, shant want it My Credit card, dost it bleed from the poisonous passion My home, you are but too close

Crave of the Day, Southern-style fried chicken, on a warm buttermilk biscuit sandwich! Are you a health nut (or Wannabe health nut?) then you are in luck. Scratch Biscuits got some good news for you: Now, you can whip up a delicious biscuit, that is good-for-your gluten-free diet. It ain't hard to be healthy, you know! So, eat away, and live well. The deal: You can BYOB. Leave your BYOB assumptions at the door as you Build Your Own Biscuit with 4 simple steps: 1/ Select your preferred biscuit: tender and moist traditional biscuit made from scratch, or fluffy gluten-free biscuit made from scratch, or better yet, you can SCRATCH the biscuit, and have the innards. 2/ Select your preferred meat: From BBQ Brisket, to buttermilk fried chicken, to black bean chili cake, and more. 3/ Select your preferred vegetable: Delicious cabbage slaw, chow chow, and more. 4/ Select your preferred sauce: Pimento cheese, basil mayo, or simply hot sauce, and more. 5/ Select your preferred other stuff: Pickled red onion, smoked cheddar, and more. 6/ BE CREATIVE! More creative, and more. Or if you are lazy, like me, it ain't a problem, they know lazy people, like us, exists. That's why they put together some insanely delicious, and creative choices for us. Breakfast for supper? They serve breakfast biscuits all day, it goes very well with some Rival Brothers coffee. Too late for coffee, no worries, they'll be serving Sip-N-Glo juices. Now tell me this ain't healthy! I got the "Fried Chicken Picnic Biscuit ($9)." It was exceptional! Very tender, flaky and moist biscuit. The luscious sandwich just melted in my mouth. It was perfect in every single way. I will make sure to pay them a second visit, and try their homemade biscuit puddin's. I'll get either the nutella Puddin', or fluffernutter Puddin'. And when I do, then I'll have what I believe is heaven on earth. Now that's what I call craving! Two Yelps. or better yet, BISCUITs.
Noel no longer works there. So do not bother asking for her anymore. That makes me take away a half star but I cannot.
Service is friendly. Food is tasty. $9 for 1 chili dog and 3 small onion rings. $6 for 8oz glass(that is 1/2 a pint) of Flying Fish Grand Cru. Those are menu prices, before tax and tip. Fail.
I do not know why Adelita is not packed. There should be a line out the door. The decor perhaps could be a little less cafeteria-esque, but the food my god the food. Really really really good.

This would've been a 5* but our waiter was not pleasant at all. When we sat down with the hostess our waiter greated us we ordered our drinks and another waiter came up after and greated us again and asked for drink order we said we already placed it with the waiter before him he was confused like we were. When the other waiter came with our drinks he asked him "oh you got this table?" I really wish the second waiter was our waiter the guy who stole his table was so unpleasant, no life seemed to be in him. There was no conversation with us when he did cone and ask how our food was I replied "delicious I bet you take a "doggy" bag home for yourself every night, he answered i don't have a dog I said oh I mean for yourself he goes no I don't at all, ?????!!!!!! ‍‍‍‍ some people need to get out of serving. It's the restaurant he works at for crying out loud! He should like the food and even if he didn't like Italian food he should carry a sense of pride for where he's employed....after all it's very expensive and the quality is superb!!! The waiter who's table it should've been served our food had great conversation with us and we felt like tipping him. We will be back when we are in Philly again but we will not be getting the waiter with a smaller frame and dark rectangle glasses.
Great food that's inexpensive in a nbrhd filled with bougie over priced resteraunts.

It's frigging ridiculously delicious. I just wish it was cleaner. I don't understand why they can't keep roaches off the RC Cola machine. Needless to say, I put up with that grossness just for a Paesanos!

Whatever you think of Otolith, and its hard not to love this tiny store, you've got to give credit to the couple behind this courageous venture. The owner gave us a 15 minute summary of what and why they are doing what they are doing. Both husband and wife are/were fishermen, he is still. They know how dire is the situation with obtaining pristine, read that which wont poison us, fish and how it is best for all of us to act sooner rather than later in trying to make the situation better. The $18.00 piece of King salmon as well as the chunk of Alaskan halibut, both frozen, that we bought were without question the finest pieces of fish that I have had in recent memory and at prices that should make Whole Foods feel shame (fat chance). And given their insider's advantage, their relationships with small suppliers takes them outside the sphere of the same old same old vendors that keep perpetuating old and pernicious ways. They are less a vendor of fine and safe seafoods than a tiny company that melds "commercial fishing experience with the biological sciences while bringing 21st century environmental awareness" to all of us. This is a venture that we all have to support.

Pros - 10 delectable brews on tap, brewed on premise. Cases, growlers, and kegs also available for purchasing. Respectable grill menu. Cons - limited seating, other customers. Other customers in their limited seating. Hours not conducive to all-day binging. Half-day binging available.

Love cheesesteaks from them always have since the first time I ordered from them but they messed up on one of my cheesesteaks. It happens but I would like it to not happen if I'm getting charged. Thanks!

All the years that I've been visiting south st & I never actually stopped in this place lol My friends and I finally decided to pay a visit. The only regret I have was the brain freeze for chugging my drink to hard LOL.

If you enjoy creative small plates and yummy gnocchi with a side of overly pretentious service, I would highly recommend Stateside. Be forewarned the happy and pleasant food runner will completely and totally make up for the pretentious server.

I haven't gone to this Olive Garden for a few years since the environment changed and people began showing up to the restaurant with pajamas. Yesterday I went and I was really impressed with the waiter, TJ. My waitress was busy and my sister and I weren't approached by her for about ten minutes of being seated. TJ noticed we weren't waited on yet and came to give us our drinks and put our appetizer in so we didn't have to wait any longer. He didn't have to do that since we weren't his table, but his professionalism and care for customers definitely showed. Food was very good also. Thanks Olive Garden and thank you TJ!
I just gotta say: the chocolate covered banana cookie thing filled with raspberry and cream. Like. Who even thought of this? And why is it not being talked about?!
I really loved the atmosphere and everything we ordered, but the server was rude as hell.

Food was great. Service not so much. The Vaca Fritta was very delicious, good portion size and nice presentation. But service hurt. The server didn't spend more than 15 seconds providing service - 5 seconds to get drink and food order, 5 seconds to drop off food, and 5 seconds to close out bill. No welcome or chat at anytime. Water never came as requested. No follow-up on empty drink. No follow-up on food (which was excellent). No dessert follow-up (Too bad!).
Place looks clean employees. Need to be more proactive at keeping kids away from the food bar. They have a tendency to be touchy feely with the food.

Move over Dinic... and Tony Luke. There's a new contender in my top 3 roast pork sandwich spots. George's is a little hole-in-the-wall, luncheonette type of shop with all of 4-5 sparse tables to squeeze into. By the looks of it, there hasn't been much, if any renovations, since it was opened 65+ years ago. Not to say it's dirty. It's just worn. But with it located in Italian Market, that's part of the charm. One bite of the roast pork sandwich and all of that was forgotten. It ain't pretty, and it ain't frilly. It doesn't need to be. The pork was so juicy and succulent. Flavorful without being overwhelming. Not heavy on the stomach. I haven't tasted anything like it. The experience gave me a new appreciation for pork - the other white meat. Yeah yeah... why does it always have to be a color thing? That's the thing. It isn't. This sandwich transcends color and you're just experiencing meat on a different level. The second time I went, I got it with broccoli rabe and sharp provolone - South Philly style. My mouth is watering as I reminisce.... *slurp* The others who say that the staff isn't friendly, I'd have to disagree. They kept asking if we were enjoying our meals. Within a few verbal volleys, the lady at the counter was giving me the full history... the secret recipe is being passed down through the family. I'd say this experience is priceless. But you can get this for less than $10! What's not to love. It's a true Italian Market/South Philly experience.
First time in Philly this place came highly recommended. The meat was good. Not enough cheese and the sandwich looks nothing like the pictures...skimpy .....WHERE's the Meat?

For months and months I would drive by this place and wonder why they were not open yet. Finally I noticed that they were and made plans to pay them a visit the next time I was in the neighborhood. I work in Northern Liberties, right up the street from Darlings and as far as I am concerned the bar is set pretty low for a good diner in this part of town. I walked in and was promptly greeted and seated. This is an improvement already. My server was equally quick to check in with me and take my order. I asked for an omelet that was not specifically listed on the menu and they happily accommodated me. I am accustomed to the Darlings egg cake folded over the contents with absolutely no cohesion except for the half melted cheese. I was so pleased that what I got from Mugshot was exactly what I believe a Diner omelet should be; eggs with the ingredients mixed in and then the cheese added and melted in the cooking process. I was also pleased that my toast was served dry with real butter on the side, which is the way I like it since I can't stand the butter blend that so many places use and then call butter. One more thing to mention in the contrast between these two places but I noticed that across the board Mugshot was at least $1 less on each thing that I compared. Bottom line, Mugshot is what I wish Darlings was and I would totally go there often if they were a tad more conveniently located. Oh well. I can still say good things about them.

Nothing will make my eyes roll in their sockets like a defective slot machine faster than a bank getting into the coffee house business. In order to seriously disrupt the one star service pedigree at most retail banks Capital One opened an honest to goodness java station in Philadelphia's Rittenhouse Square to swaddle their brand in avuncular good feelings and lash millennial tastebuds in yummy (and expensive) caffeine concoctions. Frankly, I take my money seriously and I'll easily forego the frothy cappuccino in favor of things like... I don't know... competitive interest rates and an extensive ATM network. Maybe I'm just old school about the hipness required of my bank but am I the only one who thinks it odd that a bank whose core values should spin on an axis of responsible personal finance sees their point of difference in the sale of frivolous morning dessert beverages at a usurious $8 a clip. I just know I left my copy of Personal Finance for Dummies around here somewhere. Damn, I must have left it between the couch cushions at the Capital One Cafe. Madison, a round of Double Mochas for everyone, on me. Extra Cinnamon and hold the interest.

Let me first say.. I was extremely skeptical of this place for numerous reasons... The "branding" of the store outside looks very unimpressive, poorly crafted, and not extravagant. The place replaced Saigon which was ALREADY a dead restaurant to begin with. Then we walked in, and everything changed.. (easily one of my FAVORITE Chinese restaurants next to authentic Sichuanese places to eat). I rarely comprehensively talk about food in great detail but I feel like this place needs justice done -- Environment: Again, nothing impressive as I was expecting but it was most certainly quiet. It seems as if most of the people who eat here are Penn international students who come from China (this was my first eyebrow raised.. wondered if the locals really enjoyed it.) Service: It took a while for the food to come out. We ordered and despite not having many people in the restaurant, my friend who ordered one of the lunch specials got his food in 5 min, and took my food (look under food section) and it took 15 minutes. Despite the lack of service, this place REALLY DESERVED its 5 stars from the food and price ALONE. Food: This was incredible. I feel like I don't even want to say anymore. If you want the full Northern Chinese experience, please please please get some of their special items.. I personally tried the cumin beef which was DELECTABLE. No joke: it was salty, aromatic, and oddly enough BROUGHT ME BACK down memory lane. I did indeed visit Southern China, and I KNOW this place is a NORTHERN Chinese delight; however, the food replicates EXACTLY the same one the people in China would use. Even the same exact salty meat with it's bland hand-drawn noodles were interestingly an amazing combo that I would never trade away. The dumplings weren't anything significant but much much better than the standard ones' in Philly (great texture lightly doused in hot oil). Most of their dishes comes with their cabbage and I can see exactly why this could be a turn-off. It was extremely sour and pickled. But I can tell you now, this is as accurate as it gets. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE, give this a try and a chance if you expect A QUALITY AUTHENTIC NORTHERN CHINESE CUISINE EXPERIENCE. Everything from the food to the tea is on-point. I can see why people don't like it.. it definitely does not fit the Western palate.. Price: To eat at a comfortable amount, my dish alone was around $9 while sharing dumplings for a grand total of $13.50 after tax and tip per person. This was an easy busy considering the quality of food I got (see above in food section). Can't wait to try the one in Chinatown next.
The services and the food there were great. They marinade the meat in a specific way which you never be able to do it at home-.-. I tried a couple time they all failed. Don't go for shrimp

UPDATE: In keeping with the theme that Serpico's food is great, but expensive, now that I've had a chance to look at the wine list more closely (see link in Part 2 of my opening night review below), the average markup from retail seems to be on the high side (3-5X): '09 Prum Graacher Himmelreich Kabinett, $28 wine for $110 (3.9X) '09 Trimbach Pinot Blanc 2009, $15 wine for $74 (4.9X) '10 Banshee & Rickshaw Pinot Noir, $15 wine for $50 (3.3X) NV Kanbara Bride of Fox Junmai Ginjo, $15 saki for $58 (3.9X) '11 Domaine Jerome Gradassi Chateauneuf-du-Pape, $39 wine for $170 (4.4X) I'm sorry, but $74 for a $15 bottle of wine is highway robbery in Philly. In fact, you can get this wine retail for $10.19 in NJ (7.3X markup): http://www.wineclicker.com/items/detail?itemid=463345 BTW, I didn't get an answer to my question as to whether they would let us BYOB with corkage. I doubt it. [Retail prices above are based on the average national prices from Wine-Searcher.com, for example: http://www.wine-searcher.com/find/trimbach+pinot+blanc/2009/usa ]

For the people complaining about Taco Bell, especially this location, need to grow the fuck up. Let's be real here they serve cheap inauthentic/unauthentic Mexican food. You are quite literally getting what you pay for. The staff is polite and always friendly considering they probably aren't being paid a livable wage. Enjoy your tacos and shut the hell up, you aren't special

This place is absolutely crap. I ordered shrimp lo-mein and it was not tasty whatsoever. Go to Temple Star or Temple Garden. The only reason it gets a star is because they have a little section that has signatures from Ace Hood, Ludacris, Raekwon, and Method Man.
..................................................... I have a Chinese stomach, really don't like everything I ever ordered.

BEST CHINESE IN FISHTOWN. definitely. their food is tasty and cheap, it's never made me sick either. i keep coming back. one funny thing is that when you call to order they never tell you the time it'll be ready or how much your total is, they don't even take your name or phone number. but your food's always ready in like 10 to 15 minutes. just gotta remember what you ordered since they don't have your name.

Franklin Mills hasn't been right since the 80's. Who remembers lazer tag, skating, the arcades, batting cages, bowling? That stuff is long gone. It's raggedy now. Take your local avenue strip junk shops, drop in some watered down anchors, baby mommas and crying babies, some hooligans, and sprinkle in a food court and a half... take that put a roof over it and viola. Its only redemption is that it has a movie theater. I think the only way I'll ever go back is if I'm trying to escape prison by crawling through the sewers and I just happen to pop up there. Even then, I'd blend right in.

Along with other reviewers, I must preface my comment by saying that the atmosphere and service of this restaurant was impeccable. Next, I absolutely love vegetables, and I reviewed the menu before going to the restaurant, and had read reviews regarding the best options to experience. It just didn't work out for me. In the week prior, I had gone to Vernick, and had a few of their vegetable offerings and I was totally delighted, and blown away by how fantastic they were. I wish I had something more positive to say, but I had indicated previously that their service and atmosphere is fantastic.

We came across a silent event at Vango and had a blast! The music, the views from the sky bar, definitely added to the experience. If you have a chance to head to one of these events hosted at Vango once a month, GO, club nights will never be the same!
Not bad at all for americanized Mexican food. As far as carne asadas go I would recommend not using such tough and chewy cuts of meat and serve more meat than fat and bones though

An insanely busy restaurant with good food. I had a terrible experience recently with a missing item in my order. The girl on the phone handled it very poorly, it left a bitter taste in my mouth. I was ready to forgo going back to Penang. It took my aunt having to barge in there in person to get the issue remedied. I was told on the phone that they would check the cameras to see if the "item was packed" this wording obviously didn't help. She almost disregarded that the Beef Rendang in my order was even missing. I left my name and number with her and I was going to leave it at that. My aunt decides that it was a situation that needed to be handled in person, so she goes in the store. The manager, I believe, handles it calmly and says the kitchen will now prepare it for us. I'd like to believe that this happened because they found out they did make an error on their part. I like this place. I like the food here, I like this guy--he seems to care about the restaurant. I'd give a 3.5 but I figured I'll just round up and sway people to come here instead of those other choices (like that leaf place, quality and quantity over there are both garbage nowadays). So, I would recommend this place, but I will never order delivery/pick up again. Customer service department needs a desperate re-haul. To end this on a positive note, their satay is delicious. The peanut satay sauce will have you addicted. Their Pad Thai is one of my favorites in the city and roti canai (Indian pancake) is a classic that should always be included in your meal.

Welcome to the 5 Star Club, helm! This is one of the best restaurants I've been to in a while. The location of the restaurant isn't too ideal, but they're really doing something right to draw people there. The only thing they need to change is the signage out front. I drove by it twice before finding it. Hint to those reading this: it's right next door to the Mexican restaurant. This BYOB has a limited menu, but they've managed to pack it with creativity and a certain distinction for anyone who loves dining out. All of the food tastes fresh and the best part is it's very reasonably priced for the quality of food. The most expensive item was $25. For an appetizer I had the Carrots, Chevre, Basquaise. I like carrots, but helm gave me a reason to love them here. They were smoked that gave it a completely different taste to them. They were complimented nicely with the melted chevre cheese and the peppery basquaise sauce. As for my entree, I had the NY Strip Steak, Broccoli, Jalapeno. It was a large piece of steak that came out already sliced. I usually get a steak medium, but they prepare it medium rare. I might have found a reason to change my ways! Besides the food being amazing, the service was just as good. They don't have menus, but rather a chalkboard. Instead of just reading it, the gentleman who took the orders came over and gave an extensive and detailed description of each of the dishes making it a lot easier in making a decision. This place definitely makes the list of ones to return to. My one last piece of advice is to make a reservation as it's not an entirely big restaurant.
Respectable, they don't skimp like Gia Pronto

Really wanted to love this place. I've been here twice now and the chicken has gotten better but the sides need work. Probably one of the worst biscuits I've ever had, and that really really pains me to say. The chicken (spicy) is really flavorful and tender though. Pricing is spot on as well. Really hope they work it out because I love the idea of fast casual but great food in South Philly!

The owner is a scumbag all of them , they treat their employees like crap, I worked there and quite frankly I'm happy I'm gone , I hate all of them but the employees for the most part are good , I say they have some good food and their cooks are pretty good as well. For the most part I love the hostesses but other r than that if I could give less than 1 star I would and that's sad coming from a former employee

Bonk's is a local's local bar. Came here for an Eagles game one Sunday, the place was filled with lifers from around Port Richmond, customers and employees. We came for crabs. #1 blues were about 7 dollars each. There was a special on for what they called rock crab, at two for 4 dollars. These crabs came cleaned and split. They had the same shape and flavor as a dungeness crab, except smaller and with black tipped claws. I can tell these came in frozen and reheated, but they were good nevertheless. Blue crabs are served dirty (whole, delicious "mustard" and all) with or without a pool of Bonk's juice; a briny, spicy boiling liquid that sends the sea bugs to their graves. Then they were all washed down with dollar pints of Bud Light (shitty light beer is the only beer to have with crabs). And to top it off, the fries stay impossibly crisp forever. No joke. Maybe the lukewarm crabs when served were an issue, but I can't remember. All I can recall is a bright white light followed by shell fragments everywhere.
Try the Chicken Taco Wrap... its totally money.
There was a line that reached the door when I came here. Tried a strawberry iced drink here, but it had way too much of an artificial taste for me.

Went in and probably hit a good time. There was a line, but wasn't too long. Just a few minutes later and it was getting crazy though. Had an iced mocha, great coffee! It was rich, but not sweetened. They have different sweetener options so you can get it just like you want. I'd like to give the food a try sometime. Delicious.
German chocolate brownie is really good. Very fresh and moist. I'd come back again next time I'm in philly

Food sizes are extremely small and really expensive for what it is. Food comes out at different times, which isn't an issue if there was only a small lag. I received my food and finished it before the other people at my table even got theirs. You're better off just taking a picture with the painting on the door and walking to another restaurant.
Friendly staff, and good food. Not amazing, but good and at a fair price. I came here for the Ethiopian food, so I can't comment on the coffee shop aspect.

Tamarind chicken had too much fish sauce, and Bahn Mi was inauthentic. The waitress was sweet, and the decor was calm and interesting. Nice spot to grab a drink at the bar, and listen to some chill music.

I was hankering for a top notch burger and decided to stop by here with a friend since I live in the neighborhood and have biked by many times. I'm nervous at times when a restaurant is listed as casual attire - just how casual? Upon my trips past this place since it has opened I've seen nothing but seemingly businessmen and women packed to the gills inside, so I have the ever present fear of embarrassing street-denial. Don't be worried - neither the host nor our server lost a beat upon seeing my wonderful bright purple shirt and camo shorts. If there was one aspect of dinner I was truly impressed by, it was the service. Our server was absolutely delightful and provided one of the best experiences I've had on that end in a while. Informative, prompt and with a great sense of humor, you absolutely cannot beat good service. We sat outside, which is always a plus if offered, but Fairmount Ave is a little noisy at night time, and especially so during the warmer months. I was not a fan of the rickety tables and cheap, thin-metal chairs. For food we were absolutely set on the Hickory Burgers, as neither of us had been to Rouge. Unfortunately, like everyone else in the city we had read the LaBan review from last week, and they were regrettably out. We opted to share the NY Strip and Roasted Pork Tenderloin instead. I was unimpressed with the NY Strip. It was cooked to temperature, and exceptionally moist and juicy, but seemingly lacked seasoning. The butter was good, but in a city where you can get steaks anywhere I always seem to have hit-or-miss experiences with them at all but the premier "we do steaks" places. The frites accompanying were crisp and salted just enough, but were not altogether memorable. If I'm going for a straight taste of the meat, I might seek out the Steak Tartare I saw on the menu if it's around next visit. The pork loin was also cooked very well, and I thought it was a better dish - cheaper, too. The sweet potato puree and Swiss chard seemed at odds, but the dish did work well together. We didn't BYO anything but I wish we would have. I'm a little sad, actually, to hear of their imminent acquisition of a liquor license as I do love the BYOs around the city, and this place seems perfect for one, especially with the PLCB store right on the next block down the street. I will be returning, at a minimum to have a burger, but also probably to try their seafood dishes, which seem to have more positive reviews in general. I suppose I had just suffered too large a blow hearing about the lack of burgers, and maybe that spoiled my enthusiasm on this visit.

Stopped here on my lunch break and spent the majority of my time in line waiting to order my food as the cashier was moving like a snail; and no they weren't busy, just slow. They have a wide variety of menu options to order from, which is pretty cool. I ended up ordering the fish over rice platter which I'd say was a 4-10. The rice tasted old in my opinion but the cucumber salad and pita was pretty good,I should've just gotten that. All in all this place has room for improvement if they hired more cashiers things would be smooth sailing.

OMG my school went here on a class trip in middle school! It was the first and last time I've been to the Market. I wandered around with a few classmates and we ate Chinese food for lunch and matriculated throughout the place until I felt like I found out what it would be like to be an ant in an ant farm. There was even a news story going on and we tried to be in the background but the chick who was the reporter shooed us away. This was one of many fun class trips to Philly that serve as reminders of why I love New Jersey.

They have signs on every window stating "Open 24 hours" so perhaps they had a transition phase. The service was much better this time, the food was the same (decent) and the coffee lukewarm. Don't get the lemon meringue pie.

This place is OK. If you're not from Philly and you've never orderd a steak be prepared to be scrutinized. Wit means you want cheese wiz. American means you want American cheese. The lady who works there will give you the eye and make you feel like your'e from another planet if you don't do it correctly. I wonder if she stops to think that without tourist and out of towers, this place wouldn't be open. Even with all that, I've had much better cheesesteaks....outside of Philly. This place looks like it should be in Vegas it's lit up like a christmas tree. If you go in the winter, be prepated to freeze your buns off; it's outside seating only. Go next door to the Yogurt shop and get a coffee and eat your steak in warmth,
Blonde bartender spent more time on her phone than tending the bar. Food was ok. Not worth another visit.

We had a great experience here on a Friday night in April. Philadelphia is the central location to meet when my college friends and I get together, but we've done Center City so many times, sometimes it's just not worth the hassle. We chose Manayunk, and particularly the Goat's Beard, to try something new and a hopefully find a spot where you could heard conversation. It helped that we were there the weekend preceeding Easter - most college kids were home, so the town was a bit quieter. There's a paid parking lot across down a block and across the street - Venice Island. It was $8 for the evening until midnight. We walked in around 9:30 and the bar was pretty full, but there was still room to move around. We found the hostess' stand, but it was the manager who came, greeted us, and seated us at a high-top table just next to the bar. The Goat's Beard has an EXTENSIVE cocktail list. I tried three of the signature drinks - The Goat's Beard, the Old Fashioned, and the Town & County (which was the best of the three - made with maple syrup, rye, antica, and rhubarb bitters). Prices were about $9/drink. Non-signature drinks were around $6 and beer around $4. Best part of the night? Acoustic guitarist who set up shop not far from us, covering my favorite early-2000's acoustic/alternative bands. It was like my favorite station on Pandora - but live!! Can't attest to the food - we just imbibed in the extensive drink menu! Goat's Beard is the place to go in Manayunk for late-twenties/early-thirty-something-year olds. If I lived nearby, I'd be there every weekend.

It's my favorite place in all of Philadelphia. I don't go out often (maybe 2x a week), but when I do, this place is always in the conversation. Uhhh, I'm kidding. I'm here at least once a week if not more and it's no longer part of the 2x a week conversation. I'm a regular. At least half a dozen people know my name. I love the booths around the bar. Great for inconspicuous people watching. Menu (ranked in order) Gambas - dip your bread in the sauce Mussels - dip your bread in the sauce Chicken Pimientos - dip your bread in the sauce Pan con Tomate - do not share Albondigas - dip your bread in the sauce Bravas - dip your bread in the sauce Potato Tortilla - do not share Croquettes - ok to share Empanadas - ok to share Broccoli Rabe - ok to share Calamari - ok to share I order the Gambas and the Bravas every time I'm here. I didn't even list the charcuterie. They have a build your own option which I go for once a month or so. Menu is quite descriptive on flavor profiles, which is great for the cheese portion of the menu. My cocktail of choice is the Whisky Root. The ginger bits are everything! It just makes me feel like I'm being healthy you know? I love it here...

If I was rating the natural wine list, it would be a 5. Great selection of tasty wines at what I believe are fair prices. A++++ there. That said, I had incredibly high expectations for the pizzas, but they were not met and certainly were not exceeded. Now let me preface this with this... we make a lot of pizza at home and have spent a few years mastering our own Neapolitan-style dough. We also make our own sauce and dabble in many toppings, so we are not traditional pizza lovers so to speak. The Eeva pizzas both look and sound delicious - and I love the topping selections that were offered at the time of our visit (shout out to Charlito's salami picante which I am quite obsessed with - that and their chorizo). Loved the space. Service was great. Loved the ricotta. And did I say I loved the wine list? With it being a pizza-focused place, though, I may come back someday, but I am not itching to.

Very nice service, vibe, music (which isn't too loud), and food was good! The people in my party liked their food, which ranged from the veggie burger, the brisket, the fish & chips, and more. I had asked to substitute my cole slaw for veggies, but the waiter had said the cole slaw was a small thing, so I just said nevermind not a problem! And then when my plate came out, I had a side of veggies! I thought maybe I might be charged for an extra side by when I checked the bill at the end of the meal, the veggies were nowhere to be found :) So thank you to the kind waiter for being awesome about telling us the history of the restaurant, being patient about our menu question and food choices, and for giving me my veggies! I'm no Philly local, but I thought this place was fairly priced with good food and nice atmosphere. Definitely recommend for both locals and visitors!

The service out shined the food by far. Everyone we encountered was so attentive, knowledgeable, and personable. It seemed like they sincerely enjoyed working there. The food was incredibly over salted to the point where I was going through water like a fish. I could only eat 1/3rd of my suckling pig. Definitely not impressed.

Finally, Philly has caught on and followed NYC in the endeavor of starting restos like this...c'mon, you know yuppies love tapas. Duh. I've been to Barcelona and eaten the best of the best tapas...so this review may not be fair...but to be honest, the food here was actually good. Octopus was on point. Croquetas were deelish. Iberian ham was like butta'. Olives and cheese plate was status quo. The cava wine was refreshing. Lots and lots of chicks in groups. Lots of dates all around. But where are the latin servers? Are there no hispanic people in Philly?

I've been thinking about writing this review for quite a while. The reason I've been putting it off has been the inconsistency of my experience at this market. In the past 6 months, I may have bought 5 hoagies for lunch here. The quality of each has ranged from inedible to lately two of the best italian hoagies I have ever had. Coincidentally, the last 2 hoagies I purchased during our last 2 snowstorms and the shop wasn't busy. On a normal day the line to order may be 20 people deep at times. So rather than tempt fate I will continue to make this my go to choice during blizzards and limit my culinary range to the italian hoagie.

So, to be clear, our take-out tacos were delicious, and the staff was friendly and helpful (thank you Katie for talking my boyfriend, who has dietary restrictions, through his options) but if I can't physically pick the taco up and eat it because it isn't double layered and just falls apart I'm gonna feel a certain way about paying $13 for two.

$5 breakfast on weekdays between 7 and 9, yo. The latkes are not what I would consider a latke, and kind of a gross triangular wedge of potato and onion instead, but I heartily endorse the biscuit. They do not fuck up the eggs, which I appreciate.
Good pizza but they struggle terribly with delivery. Expect a least an hour wait any day of the week. Often shows up cold and hard.

Love the food there! Parmagana pizza (prosciutto spinach) and steamed mussels with Alfredo sauce and white wine! Audience is ok, sometimes very loud but OK in general! Love the live music in the evening!!!
This sandwich shop is so awesome. 5 bucks or so. Fantastic bread. Great traditional sandwich. Friendly employees. Bail on Subway or Hoagies or Grinders or Cheesteak and give it a shot.

Finally had me some Home Slice and ive got to tip my hat off to you boys. Well done. Being a pizza snob (i dont rate pizza unless it falls into the same category as Delorenzo's Trenton, Vince's NE Philly, Denino's Staten Island, you get me...) I didnt expect much from this foo-foo Vegan friendly spot. I was pleasantly surprised. The pie was crisp with just enough cheese to make it stretch just enough before tearing away with each bite. ill be back!

Came here earlier on a Sunday morning just before the lunch rush and got seated immediately. Our family of 5 ordered all three soup dumpling dishes, a beef chow fun, a bean curd dish, and two appetizers. But I'll just focus on the soup dumplings. The dough was thicker than usual, but it was in good proportion to all the meat and soup! There's really not much difference in flavor between the pork and crab buns, so I would just stick with the pork ones from now on. But great soup flavor and meat stuffing. The beef chow fun had the crucial pan smoked flavor.

The food was good and our server was friendly and attentive. We went in after a show at the Kimmel Center around lunchtime on a Saturday. The hostesses though, were terrible. When we walked in they were too engrossed in their conversation and ignored us for a good 2 minutes. When we finally got seated, the hostesses were MIA and people kept walking in and getting ready to leave because there was nobody to greet them and get them seated.

This review is for happy hour only** After all the hype I was pretty disappointed by Porta, I'm sad to say :( The vibe is really cool overall, with garage doors open to the street and shared, picnic table seating (on one side of the restaurant).. but here's why it didn't meet my expectations: -Happy Hour cocktails were drenched in simple syrup to the point that they were inedible. Not worth $6. -The sliders (meatball and peppers) from the happy hour menu were cold when we got them and the baguette was so hard that we couldn't even bite through the sliders -The Three Trees salad was supposed to have prosciutto (yum) but instead came with crunchy bacon bits that tasted out of a container. It was soaked in a bitter vinaigrette. Would not recommend. We left bummed. I have heard that the pizza is good so I will plan to try that if I ever make it back and will update if so.

Ordered take out after having eaten in the restaurant. The restaurant experience was great. Loved every single bite, super flavorful! Unfortunately the take out was not at the level I remembered. The Lamb vindaloo was good, definitely a small portion but good. The saag paneer was very soupy, lacking the creaminess and the flavor that you would expect. The "baby eggplant cooked in hot tamarind sauce" was soupy and full of garlic cloves Finally the paneer dosa was super greasy.... I love this place and I really hope this was a one off experience!

Grew up in that area. Glad to hear of all great restaurants up Passyunk Avenue and stateside being number one. We ran. Ok small plate place = small plates of okay food for same price as regular size meals at other great restaurants. Oysters were delicious yet ate one that had off smell and taste and I couldnt eat anymore oysters. Just mentioned it to waitress got a blank stare. Drinks were fun to try since they were olden day drinks that you only hear about. But would have enjoyed having full happy tummy for $ we spent from the NUMBER 1best of phila.
Don't use DoorDash or any other ordering service. Your food will not show up. This has happened to me twice now. They have their own driver but for some reason our order never gets delivered.

their parking lot is a nightmare but once you circle it like 70 times, once inside its worth it..it is pretty tight with a cart but the prices and quick lines make up for it. I'm a bargain shopper so I use store brands and shop rite brand is top notch, the store card helps you save more money as well, so if you want to stretch your dollar I recommend shopping here.

If you have a hankering for sweets, look no further than Swiss Haus. Having heard of the cronut for what seems like forever, I finally decided to give my husband something he would not forget on a snowy Valentine's Day - food. I was shocked to see that the cronut is actually a monstrosity. Seriously folks, they're big. But I got two anyway, chocolate and vanilla. Because you know, I had to try both flavors! The cronut did not disappoint, but really one is enough for two people to share and at $5 a piece, you probably want to bring a few friends with you. They only make them on the weekdays, so if you're looking for something sweet for Saturday or Sunday brunch, grab them on Friday morning. Excited to try some of the other sweet-toothed options at Swiss Haus, as they looked divine.

Would love to able to review the food but couldn't, walked out after an hour and watching 5 other tables get served before us. Their food looked delicious though. Smelled great too. Coffee and water was pretty good. While nice, no one working there gave an excrement about what happened. (Update, they emailed me and offered me a gift card, didn't take it I was just happy to be acknowledged, so that was cool of them, thanks)

Used to love this place. Took my gf here on our first date and all.. Fat Salmon has overtaken my heart on this one. I dont know what happened RAW, theyre just better. However, if you are here, the Tuna tar tar will is the best. If this joint ever loses that appetizer, im afraid itll be the end of my 3 yr love affair with Raw

When some people go to Philadelphia, they think of Philly cheesesteaks. When they think of cheesesteaks, they usually think of either Pat's or Geno's. Those of you who talk to me about food probably already know that when I think of Pat's or Geno's, I think of paying ten dollars for the privilege of standing in a line, waiting for half an hour, and getting substandard tourist-trap tier food. After the experience, most people now need to brainwash themselves into thinking that they've made some sort of good financial and or culinary decision, lest their common sense takes over and they realize that they've been suckered by an establishment that prides themselves in serving fake cheese from an aerosol can on top of meat so dry and haphazardly made that even pre-2000's era Taco Bell would not think to use it in their food. Enter Koja, a Korean place that does a real cheesesteak, with real cheese, bulgogi meat, and can give it some heat if you want it to. For the same price, or a little cheaper, you get a much better cheesesteak with some stuff on the side, with none of the soul-wrenching guilt. Although I've only been twice, and only ever had their bulgogi cheesesteak, I've gotta say it's probably the best cheesesteak I've had in Philly. I've been to the famous, less-famous, and local stores, and this place beats them all. The meat is great, and they use real cheese. Definitely get it spicy!

Very good pizza. Good delivery. Had this pizza many times before. Never dissappoints if you order pizza. One time I got a Greek salad. I will stick to pizza. Greek salad was mediocre at best & used canned olives. Big turn off.

Searched out this spot for breakfast today. Sounded great, so off I went with my wife and daughter. Sadly, they were closed today. Best to call ahead if you are going there. Love the outside environment, except it was pouring rain, off to Cake we went. Delicious!

The quality at Rybread has come down. When they opened, they made a lot of absolutely outstanding sandwiches, but I've noticed more and more corners being cut despite their wild success. As a for instance, the San Antonio, formerly an absolutely incredible cold roast-beef sandwich, just melt-in-your-mouthy deliciousness, has had its roast beef replaced with... some other kind. Maybe it's a good brand like Boar's Head -- I'm willing to believe that -- but regardless, it certainly hasn't been a good change. Similarly, I've noticed a decline in the amount of meat and the amount of various toppings that make it onto the sandwiches. It's still a fine sandwich place -- the best among zero competition in the neighborhood -- but it used to be a GREAT place, and it's depressing that it just... isn't anymore.

Went for happy hour with a friend. Experience is as follows: Drinks: meh Happy hour snacks: ok Service: very good, friendly Atmosphere: amazing! Drinks and food were ok but the restaurant decor literally made our mouths drop. It is too cute. Bartender that did happy hour for us was super friendly and accommodating!

this place is 5 stars in the you get what you pay for and what you are expecting category. ok first off the drinks and the food is fairly priced. you usually do not have to wait for a table. the wait staff is attentive and the service is good. they seat big parties and do not have problems splitting bills or taking my multiple restaurant . com coupons i'm always using. secondly they have all types of vegan options, clearly labeled on the menu. third they have KARAOKE that is so much fun! seriously try it out. this place isnt fancy, it isnt trendy, it isnt high brow BUT it is affordable, comfortable, fun and a GREAT place to go if you want to have a nice dinner and dinks with friends

I think given our experience, a 3 is generous but there were some aspects of this place that were nice. Our server was nice and they have a lot of vegan options which is always exciting for me (and why we came here). It's rare to find a vegan french toast when dining out and I was so excited for it. It was hands down the worst breakfast I have ever eaten. When they brought it out, I thought it was a chocolate bread but no...it was burnt. It's just deep fried bread. There was so much oil and grease in it that I felt sick. With each bite, my mouth became saturated with oil and the bread seemed to disintegrate. I can't even explain how bad it was. My husband ordered the regular chicken parm sandwich and said it was good but he felt sick afterwards too. We had to cancel our plans for the rest of the day and get a ride home where we both ended up throwing up. Part of me wants to come back to try the other menu items but I don't know if I can given how horrible our experience was today. If I do though, I will stay far away from the vegan French toast.

I finally got to try this place! It was better than i expected! The food took a bit to come out but it was worth the wait. I had the karai and it was very flavorful. The fatty pork was cooked just right. I wish there were more seats available. People were stalking people for tables... umm felt like i was in Flushings Chinatown Mall. Overall it was good. FYI spoke to the cashier and they are putting more tables in. Yay!

I'm not a HUGE Mexican food fan, but there is no way I can give this place anything less than 5 stars. It's a well-done place, a great atmosphere, and a pretty cool location. The food is darn tasty...I've enjoyed it as much as any other restaurant in the city (but I keep my selections simple, ya know?) The place can be crowded...but never packed or ridiculous, etc. Reservations make it easy. Parking (local, free) is not much of an issue either. Prices are decent...and the margaritas are top-notch! This place is just another piece of the culinary puzzle that makes Philadelphia the best food city in the world! How dare New Yorkers call Philly their "sixth borough"! They can keep their overpriced steakhouses and "New York" soft pretzels...what a joke!

I came here with a friend on a Sunday afternoon. We were in Philly for the night, looking for something nearby the hotel before hitting the road. I have to be honest, I was impressed. The menu was quite nice, the food well prepared and presented, the service attentive, and the price very reasonable.

Food is outstanding! Atmosphere is great! Outside bar is fun and lively! But...the bartenders. They have a chip on their shoulder. Too many times I've been at the outside bar and they don't even acknowledge your existence. They walk back and forth in front if you without a glance. At least say "hello I'll be with you shortly." They're slow, unfriendly, and have an attitude. And this is when it's not crowded. There have been several times my wife and I thought of going but decided to venture elsewhere because of the bartenders. I'll be back because it's practically in my backyard and the food is good but not as much as we would if the bartenders had a personality and dropped the attitude.

Picked this spot to hide from all the pre-Super Bowl shows and hype. It was about half full inside but only one bartender working both the bar and those of us sitting at tables for food. Overall good experience and the food came out quick and hot. Only disappointment was the onion rings appetizer - completely tasteless. We tried the dip it came with, adding salt and pepper - it was just very flavorless coating. We each tried one and didn't touch them again. The bartender didn't ask how we were enjoying things because honestly he was really busy, so it was a shame to leave an entire plate of food behind.

I don't like to experiment with brunch food. When I'm on the verge of vomiting and still feeling drunk from the night before, the last thing i want is a burrito stuffed with eggs and avocado. I like omelets covered with ketchup, toasted bagels covered with cream cheese and endless cups of orange juice.

The food is ok, but we have had better here in the past. The main reason we went was for the cheese fries. This was always our hot spot for them. Things have obviously changed. We ordered 2 large cheese fries for the table. We ended up leaving an entire basket of fries that did not have cheese. When we asked if they would put more cheese, we were told that they would charge us. When I asked why they would charge us when it is obvious that it wasn't enough cheese we were told that they use a specific amount. If we can't get good cheese fries here I guess we will go across the street to Five Guys.

I'm giving 5 stars bc it's Black owned and I'm always rooting for everybody Black. But truthfully, i wasn't that impressed and prob wouldn't order again. I had the red velvet waffle fried chicken sandwich. It was just ok. My expectations were a little high...maybe other items are better but it's just blah to me.

Ordered a Caesar salad with shrimp but received a salad w/ tomatoes and red peppers. I didn't ask for that. But I think they were trying to compensate for the missing components of the Caesar, whatever the case, Would have been polite to put them on the side or give me the choice to choose a differ salad. They did take my name and number when I ordered.

I have been here 4 times. The place looks really cool. The service as noted in other reviews is lackluster and unprofessional. The servers look sloppy and lack attentiveness - but I guess that is what Northern Liberties is about. You can tell too when you look at the condiments on the table- they could be cleaner. The kitchen closes weirdly for one hour between 4-5. All that being said - I will be back. The brisket sandwich is the best. I get it with less butter (if you don't it has way too much butter) Fries are awesome. The bottled beer comes out a little too warm - we all want nice cold beers. The bourbon pecan pie with sweet potato ice cream is excellent. I also had the chile rellano and it was awesome as well. Really different than expected and I love that. Oh, and the soda is off too... it is not good. When it was Deuce's the soda was not good either - maybe they kept the same lines. Even with the service and beverage flaws, the food is SO GOOD (kudos to the chef)- I will be back. Love the hours too. Being open late night until 1am is a bonus. It is not often I go to a place with medicore service because the food is so good!

Good ramen. Hostess was rude and looked like she was the waitress too so she was running around. Got seated after 30 mins at the bar even though we came before other people and asked for the table and didn't give it to us but gave it to people after us. Rude how she didn't care. Plates were thrown in front of us instead of put down gently since they were in a rush.
